content.location: Crack on left side of the wall.

climbs.name: Where Have all the Cowboys Gone?
climbs.fa: Brad Singer and Rob Stauder, August 1998

content.description: This is the bolted line on the far right side of Resaquita Wall. "Cowboys" starts at the corner, moving up and left onto a ledge. Continue up and left past an overlap. The crux comes high, moving over a small roof and into a flaring groove. Top out on easier holds. A fun climb on overhanging rock.

Climb up the first two bolts of

My Heroes Have Always Been Old Guys

.   Where that route breaks left continue straight up with a long static reach to a shallow rounded break.

Match up on this shallow break and make a longer reach to a better break, below the fourth bolt.  The next reach is longer but both the starting and finishing holds of the move are better than before so go for it.

With the last break reached, make frustrating moves on the loose kitty litter rock until you are up at the anchors.
content.location:
Climbs the wall between

My Heroes Have Always Been Old Guys

, and

Where Have all the Cowboys Gone

.

content.description: A face climb with the crux at the first bolt.
content.location: Left most climb of the wall.

content.description: An open project as of the release of Brad Singer's guidebook.

climbs.name: My Heroes Have Always Been Old Guys

content.description:
Starts about 10' left of

Where Have all the Cowboys Gone?

(5.10b) at a short right-facing flake which is the start for both this route and

Sureshot

(5.12a).

Lieback the starting flake and trend left up slightly overhanging rock past several horizontals to a reachy crux at the 3rd bolt (shorter climbers may need to pop for the distant hold) as you stretch from one horizontal to the next. Above the crux the angle relents and moderate off-vertical face climbing leads to another crux (poor rock) past the 5th bolt before topping out onto a large ledge with anchors.

A direct finish to this route continues straight up past the 2nd bolt and is called

Sureshot

(5.12a).
